[S2] A specialist in macroeconomics and public finance, he has contributed to a range of fields, including climate change and carbon taxation, the global macroeconomic transition and the future of economic power, inequality, fiscal progressivity, economic guides to personal financial behavior, banking reform, marginal taxation and labor supply, healthcare reform, and social security. [S5] After three years as a postdoctoral fellow at UCLA, he taught as an assistant professor at Yale University from 1980 to 1981, and then as an associate professor at Yale till 1984, during which time he was a research associate at the Cowles Foundation (1980-1984), and served on the Council of Economic Advisers as a senior economist (1981-1982). [S6] He became a professor of economics at Boston University in 1984, where he twice chaired its Department of Economics, and was named a William Warren Fairfield Professor in 2009.
